title: Ticket #6924: Python Bindings: cluster handle objects
description:
Right now, the Python bindings API is mostly built from the point of view of a pool admin: when you want to submit, query, act, or edit, you go to the Schedd. This makes perfect sense for admins because they don't own any particular cluster of jobs, and they are aware of the topology of the pool.

However, users don't typically care about the Schedd. They care about submitting a cluster of jobs and then monitoring its progress, possibly editing its attributes or querying it. The first half of this was made much easier by the introduction of the Submit object in the bindings. This ticket addresses the second half (query, act, edit) by having a rich Cluster object. This object knows which Schedd its jobs live on and implements query, act (and possibly specialized hold, release, etc.), and edit methods that automatically target only the clusterid the jobs belong to.

Depending on exactly how much (if any) of the existing API we want to break, there may be a variety of ways to get a Cluster:

1. The existing Submit.queue and Submit.queue_with_itemdata methods could return Cluster. This can be done without breaking queue_with_itemdata by pulling the SubmitResult methods up into the Cluster as well, but it would break users of queue. 2. Introduce a new Submit.submit method which has the semantics of queue_with_itemdata, but returns a Cluster. 3. Ask a Schedd for a handle to a cluster: Schedd.handle(clusterid). 4. Construct it directly: Cluster(clusterid, schedd).

(All names up for debate...)

All of this will be implemented via pure-Python wrappers over the existing C++ bindings code. One change may be necessary in the underlying bindings: it would be useful for a Transaction to store and expose which Schedd it was created from. This could maybe be implemented in the Python wrapper as well, although it would probably be less stable.
